{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3421823,"name":"","username":"Michael888","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/8e8cbc/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-09-08T06:37:43.406Z","cooked":"

Hi Everyone, for swerve drives this year I was wondering if it was possible to use the built in spark max pid controllers to control the turn/angle/spin motor in a swerve module.

Last year I used a normal the WPILib PIDController. I want to use the motor controllers’ pid controllers in position mode, but I am not sure how to do that cause I don’t know how to link them up to use the absolute encoders.

Last year code snippets/idea

// INIT
    turnSparkMax = new CANSparkMax(config.turnID(), MotorType.kBrushless);

    turnFeedback = new PIDController(turnKp.get(), 0, turnKd.get());
    turnFeedback.enableContinuousInput(-Math.PI, Math.PI);

    cancoder = new CANcoder(config.absoluteEncoderChannel());

// Periodic
    setTurnVoltage(
          turnFeedback.calculate(getCancoderAngle().getRadians(), angleSetpoint.getRadians()));

What I want to do snippets/idea

// INIT
   turnSparkMax = new CANSparkMax(config.turnID(), MotorType.kBrushless);

    turnFeedback = turnSparkMax.getPIDController();
    turnFeedback.setP(turnKp.get())
    turnFeedback.setD(turnKd.get())

    cancoder = new CANcoder(config.absoluteEncoderChannel());

// SET MODULE STATES
      turnFeedback.setReference(angleSetpoint.getRadians(), ControlType.kSmartMotion);

For extra info: Using spark max with neos for drive and turn motors in modules, as well as cancoder. MK4i Swerve Module – Swerve Drive Specialties

It’s definitely possible to use the built-in PID controllers for bot swerve module rotation and drive. That’s what we’ve done in our library.

github.com

GitHub - lasarobotics/PurpleLib: Custom library for 418 Purple Haze

Custom library for 418 Purple Haze

Michael888:

I am not sure how to do that cause I don’t know how to link them up to use the absolute encoders.

So the main idea is to use the internal relative encoder within the NEO for closed loop control, and simply use the absolute encoder to initialize the starting offset, or maybe periodically correct/update the offset.

Other configurations which allow motor controllers to talk to absolute encoders are possible, but it would require different wiring, and its largely unnecessary compared to simply using them to initialize an offset from the relative encoder.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-09-08T07:51:47.069Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":100,"readers_count":99,"score":25.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":470923,"topic_slug":"how-to-use-built-in-position-pid-controller","display_username":"Eric Ward","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":35208,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3637 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-use-built-in-position-pid-controller/470923/3","custom_user_title":"3637 Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":true,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3421839,"name":"viggy96","username":"viggy96","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/viggy96/{size}/252784_2.png","created_at":"2024-09-08T09:03:02.810Z","cooked":"

I would disagree that they’re unnecessary. The MAXSwerve template for example uses the absolute encoder for PID directly, rather than seeding the internal motor encoder.

This configuration is also possible if using an appropriate adapter to use a REV through bore encoder or a Redux Canandmag directly connected to a Spark Max.

It’s a totally valid and easy way to do things, and reduces CAN bus utilization.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-09-08T09:05:00.636Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":85,"readers_count":84,"score":27.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":470923,"topic_slug":"how-to-use-built-in-position-pid-controller","display_username":"viggy96","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":35208,"username":"bathtubed","name":"Eric Ward","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bathtubed/{size}/220364_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24613,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"418 Mentor | Tries to be smart"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-use-built-in-position-pid-controller/470923/4","custom_user_title":"418 Mentor | Tries to be smart","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3421840,"name":"Eric Ward","username":"bathtubed","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bathtubed/{size}/220364_2.png","created_at":"2024-09-08T09:22:48.707Z","cooked":"

The benefit is niche, hence “largely unnecessary.”
The main benefit is accounting for backlash in the system, which COTS swerve modules don’t have much of, unless there’s another benefit I’m not seeing.

I don’t really see the CAN bus utilization argument, in that configuration you’ll need to transmit the data back to the RIO anyway for odometry.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-09-08T09:22:48.707Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":79,"readers_count":78,"score":20.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":470923,"topic_slug":"how-to-use-built-in-position-pid-controller","display_username":"Eric Ward","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":24613,"username":"viggy96","name":"viggy96","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/viggy96/{size}/252784_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":35208,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3637 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-use-built-in-position-pid-controller/470923/5","custom_user_title":"3637 Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3421841,"name":"viggy96","username":"viggy96","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/viggy96/{size}/252784_2.png","created_at":"2024-09-08T09:28:11.447Z","cooked":"

It can simplify the code to just use the absolute encoder directly.

And using a CANCoder does inherently cause more traffic, it’s sending out more status frames on the bus. You can decrease their frequency, but they’ll still be there.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-09-08T09:28:11.447Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":71,"readers_count":70,"score":44.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":470923,"topic_slug":"how-to-use-built-in-position-pid-controller","display_username":"viggy96","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":35208,"username":"bathtubed","name":"Eric Ward","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bathtubed/{size}/220364_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24613,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"418 Mentor | Tries to be smart"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-use-built-in-position-pid-controller/470923/6","custom_user_title":"418 Mentor | Tries to be smart","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3421842,"name":"viggy96","username":"viggy96","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/viggy96/{size}/252784_2.png","created_at":"2024-09-08T09:31:38.943Z","cooked":"

It’s also possible to “fuse” the encoders, by constantly syncing the internal motor encoder to the absolute encoder value. This will act more like the CTRE FusedCANCoder mode.

If I’m remembering correctly, that’s the “better” way to do it. This is the case as it does the calculation on the spark max, rather than the Rio.
